46. Who do you consider to have been the outstanding pioneer farmers of your district? Give some reasons for your choice, such as the earliest, most successful, most helpful to newcomers, contributing most to the public life and improvement of the community.

B. P. Richardson, who was also a farmer, Old Settler, was a member of Parliament at various periods, and was a prominent figure in the settlement of the district. He was a hard worker and a good neighbor, and his name will always be remembered.

He was a great friend to all, and his kindness will be remembered by many. He was a fair judge, and his word was as good as his bond. He was a man of integrity, and his honesty will be remembered by all who knew him.

He died on October 11th, 1911, and was buried in the old cemetery near the town. His memory will be cherished by all who knew him.

45. Whom do you consider to have been the outstanding pioneer farmers of your district? Give some reasons for your choice, such as the earliest, most successful, most helpful to newcomers, contributing most to the public life and development of the community.

B. P. Richardson, who was also a lawyer, R. S. Lake, who was a member of Parliament at Ottawa for three decades, Mr. Adams.

Mr. Skillittes was a big settlement man and had a large farm. He had cattle, one of the first big machines, tractors, plow, machinery, and he never worked on the land himself but had a farm manager and other men, and government or some one arranged with him to train men from overseas how to farm.

and the family. When we first went from Brandon, there was a great deal of excitement. We were very young then, and all the people we knew from our own town. And all the things we heard about the family, I could not believe.

The house we lived in was very small, but my parents were very kind to us. They always made sure we had enough food and clothes. We went to school every day, and my father taught me how to read and write.

We also had a garden where we grew vegetables and fruits. It was very productive, and we always had plenty to eat.

One day, we decided to go on a trip to see the countryside. We took a train and traveled for several hours. It was very exciting, and we saw many interesting things along the way.

When we arrived at our destination, we were very tired, but we were happy to be there. We stayed for a few days and visited many places.

On our last day, we said goodbye to everyone and returned home. It was a wonderful trip, and we will always remember it.

We ended the day at the Pearl City Hotel. The family of Mr. Petersen held us in high regard. We visited their residence and had a delightful visit.

The next morning we returned to Mount Carmel Church where we heard a very moving message. It was a time of great spiritual renewal and inspiration.

After lunch, we visited the Muir National Monument. The natural beauty was breathtaking.

As we left the area, we stopped at a nice restaurant for dinner. It was a wonderful meal, and we enjoyed each other's company.

Before heading home, we stopped at the visitor center to purchase some souvenirs.

It was a wonderful trip, and we are grateful for the opportunity to be able to visit such a beautiful place.
